weapons.name: potential manuport
weapons.description: It looks like this rock wants a passage. As long as you keep it with you, it will protect you.

weapons.name: polarized sheet
weapons.description: It's a polarized sheet. It shows Fattuzu in light.

weapons.name: sharp polyhedron
weapons.description: You should never leave your house without a sharp polyhedron in your pocket.

weapons.name: armored manuport
weapons.description: << I'm a hitchhiker, can you give me a lift... please? >>

weapons.name: transparent polygon
weapons.description: Splits light into colored beams that blind enemies. Polarized sunglasses recommended.

weapons.name: armored brench
weapons.description: It looks the same as any armored branch you've seen before. It hurts a lot when used with dexterity.

weapons.name: Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device
weapons.description: It looks like the Zero Point Energy Field Manipulator but besides lifting things it opens portals... Of course it doesn't work, but you can effectively slam it into things.

weapons.name: Deliverance by Tediore (Shotgun)
weapons.description: Allow me to deliver my bullet to your head.

weapons.name: tesseract
weapons.description: Is an Optical Character Recognition tool. That is, it will recognize and read the text embedded in images. Did you think it was a deadly weapon like in The Cube?

weapons.name: great attractor
weapons.description: It's a gravitational anomaly in intergalactic space and the apparent central gravitational point of the Laniakea Supercluster.

weapons.name: The Soul Cube
weapons.description: Is an ancient Martian artifact and the most powerful weapon in Doom 3.

curses.name: self-luminous red
curses.description: It's the impossible version of red.

curses.name: hyperbolic orange
curses.description: It's the impossible version of orange.

curses.name: stygian blue
curses.description: It's the impossible version of blue.

curses.name: Discourse on the Method of Rightly Conducting One's Reason and of Seeking Truth in the Sciences
curses.description: << Car ce n'est pas assez d'avoir l'esprit bon, mais le principal est de l'appliquer bien.>>

curses.name: falsidical paradox
curses.description: Packs a surprise, but it is seen as a false alarm when we solve the underlying fallacy. Good for Easy Enemies.

curses.name: cluster point
curses.description: A Cluster point of a set S in a topological space X is a point x that can be approximated by points of S: every neighbourhood of x also contains a point of S other than x itself. A limit point of a set S does not itself have to be an element of S.

curses.name: Gödel's completeness theorem for first-order predicate calculus
curses.description: Every syntactically consistent, countable first-order theory has a finite or countable model. This establishes a correspondence between semantic truth and syntactic provability in first-order logic: Gödel proved that first order logic is semantically complete but it is not syntactically complete, since there are sentences expressible in the language of first order logic that can be neither proved nor disproved from the axioms of logic alone.

curses.name: Aleph Naught
curses.description: Cardinality of Reals. You see, the cartesian product of a countable number of countable set is uncountable.

curses.name: Logistic Map
curses.description: Is a polynomial mapping of degree 2, often cited as an archetypal example of how complex, chaotic behaviour can arise from very simple non-linear dynamical equations.

curses.name: integral of a real multivariate function
curses.description: A function of several real variables is a function with more than one argument, the input variables take real values, while the output may be real or complex.

curses.name: veridical paradox
curses.description: Packs a surprise, but the surprise quickly dissipates itself as we ponder the proof. Good for Medium enemies.

curses.name: Comic Sans
curses.description: If you love it, you don't know much about typography. If you hate it, you really don't know much about typography either, and you should get another hobby.

curses.name: Somebody Else's Problem Field
curses.description: A SEP is something we can't see, or don't see, or our brain doesn't let us see, because we think that it's Somebody Else's Problem. The brain just edits it out, it's like a blind spot.

curses.name: not in my back yard
curses.description: Anywhere, but not in my back yard.

curses.name: Axiom of Choice
curses.description: The cartesian product of non-empty sets is non-empty. Caution: may raise paradoxes.

curses.name: antinomy
curses.description: Packs a surprise that can be accomodated by nothing less than a repudiation of part of our conceptual heritage. This is tough.

curses.name: continuum hypothesis
curses.description: There is no set whose cardinality is strictly between that of the integers and the real numbers.

curses.name: Ultimate Insult
curses.description: Capable of crippling even the toughest pirate's ego.

curses.name: Marcellus Wallace's briefcase
curses.description: <What's in the case?> <My boss's dirty laundry.> <Your boss makes you do his laundry?> <When he wants it cleaned.> <Sounds like a shit job.> <I was thinking the same thing.>

curses.name: Riemann zeta function
curses.description: Full of trivial zeroes.

consumables.modification: You could never live without it in a situation like this.
consumables.bag with red gummy bears: They are full of glucose, perfect for synthesizing ATP.
consumables.gommo: << What are these atrocious grimaces?> << What grimaces? >> << These!>> << Which ones? >> << The ones you are doing with your crippled mouth! >>
consumables.Advanced Tea Substitute: A liquid which is almost, but not quite, entirely unlike tea.
consumables.suspicious mushrooms: These seemingly delicious mushrooms have a rather sus appearance...
consumables.panna cotta: The panna cotta IS the message.

mana rechargers.name: major Fern potion
mana rechargers.description: Seriously, this stuff is tough. Please consume in moderation.
